And Congress would embrace a decision by the Biden administration to remain committed to nuclear modernization.
I believe Congress will continue to support modernizing our nuclear enterprise, in order to ensure that we have a capable and effective deterrent, supported by a modern infrastructure.
The decisions we make today will define the deterrent we field in the next fifteen years. We expect this force to be the bedrock of our national security for at least the next four decades.
Failing to modernize, and allowing our forces to age until they become obsolete, only makes future arms control agreements less likely‚Äînot more.

Some of my colleagues argue that canceling U.S. modernization programs could inspire Russia and China to do the same and create an opening for arms control negotiations.
 
However, looking at the behavior of China and Russia over the past 25 years, this is clearly not the case.

It‚Äôs clear that nuclear deterrence will continue to be vital to our security for the foreseeable future. The current modernization program of record is the most prudent and cost-effective approach to ensuring that our nation continues to field a capable nuclear deterrent.

In anticipation of the Nuclear Posture Review, we‚Äôve seen renewed debate on many modernization programs. However, I remain confident that the Biden administration will continue on the modernization path set by the Obama administration and followed by the Trump administration.
We continue to read reports of China building up its nuclear arsenal. This is not the time to let our deterrent age out.
The Senate #FY22NDAA passed out of committee with a solid bipartisan vote fully supporting our nuclear forces at a time when global threats are rising.

As the ranking member on the Strategic Forces subcommittee, it was great to virtually join the Annual Deterrence Summit today to discuss #FY22NDAA and the importance of modernizing our nuclear forces.
